body: A young Brooklyn mother accused of killing her 7-week-old daughter had been cited for taking another daughter into a place where drugs were used and had been compelled to take anger management courses this year, the authorities said yesterday. The mother, Francesca Johnson, has said that she shook her daughter, Armani, on Friday until the infant
title: Mother Admits Shaking Baby, Officials Say

body: A Brooklyn woman cited for abuse or neglect of her children on three separate occasions in the past was charged over the weekend with second-degree murder in the death of her 7-week-old daughter, the police and child welfare officials said. The medical examiner's office said that the girl suffered a brain hemorrhage after she was beaten on the
title: Accused of Neglect in Past, Mother Is Charged in Death

body: A woman was killed and her 10-month-old infant critically injured yesterday when a van collided with a car, sending the van spinning out of control into the mother and child walking in the crosswalk, the police said. No summonses were immediately issued or charges filed, the police said. The woman, Christine Hunnicutt, 39, of Brooklyn, was pushing
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mother Dies In Collision

body: NO game this weekend because, officially, the season is over, though Pudgie Walsh has had the inescapable feeling of it being one game and a grand gesture short. His Brooklyn Mariners went 10-0 in the Garden State Football League of the semipro variety, but to put away the playbook he typically forsakes for his famed wild hunches would be akin to
title: Sports of The Times; It's 'One More for Danny and Courtney'

body: FAJNSOD-Eleanore. We mourn her passing on November 13, 2001, after a tenacious battle against pancreatic cancer. Elly was born December 26, 1938, in Brooklyn, daughter of Irving and Rae (Widomlansky) Wilkes, and graduated Thomas Jefferson H.S. While living in the Glenwood Projects, she worked at South Shore H.S., lastly as a paraprofessional. After
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FAJNSOD, ELEANORE

body: CRAWFORD-Robert J. On September 11, 2001 during the performance of his duties as a New York City firefighter (Safety Batallion). He was lost in The World Trade Center disaster while in the process of evacuating civilians. Beloved husband of Dorothea (Mallon), dearest father of Christine, Mark R., Jennifer Eppolito, Rachel V. Connor and Matthew J.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CRAWFORD, ROBERT J.

body: THOUGH having long withstood the national economic doldrums, the real estate market in the New York metropolitan region was already slipping toward a slowdown by Sept. 11, housing economists and specialists say. Now the economists are wondering whether there will be a sharp V-shaped dip and rebound or a prolonged U-shaped slump. Within that
title: A Market Equation Full of Unknowns

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

body: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County today. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Mayor Mark Green Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum Comptroller William
title: Primary Choices

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. ANTIETAM, Brownies, 169 Avenue A, between 10th and 11th Streets, East Village, (212) 420-8392. There's no doubt that the centerpiece of Antietam is Tara Key, the guitar goddess
title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

body: Brooklyn voters have a chance this year to enliven New York's City Council with the kind of energy, intelligence and independence unrivaled in city politics in many years. Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: What does Angela Yurman know about the Battle of Brooklyn? ''Just living in Brooklyn is a battle every day,'' she says. In fact, Mrs. Yurman, 59, is well aware that she has been surrounded by ghosts of the battle her entire life. She grew up across the street from the Old Stone House on the edge of Park Slope, a reconstruction of a 1699 Dutch
title: Washington Fought Here; Who Knew?; On 225th Anniversary, Battle of Brooklyn Is Little-Known Chapter

body: Dr. Kendall Stewart had a hammertoe waiting. He is a podiatrist by profession. He will fix whatever bothers the foot. He took a bit of time to talk politics, for he is running for City Council in the 45th District in central Brooklyn. Like who isn't. So is an elementary school teacher. So is a rent examiner. So is a college professor. So are
title: Who's in Running For Council Seat? Almost Everybody

body: Last year's surging economy and the related jump in major construction projects in New York fueled the largest increase in spending on lobbyists in at least a decade, as developers turned to lawyers and other well-connected professionals to urge city officials to give them permits needed before any shovels could hit the ground. Over all, $14.5
title: While Economy Boomed, Money for Lobbyists Soared

body: ''A house to the Caribbean man is something very important,'' Samuel E. Palmer was saying. ''He has to have a house, as opposed to an apartment. Whatever happens, the house comes first, so you can have a family and your friends can meet there. So when I came here, the desire also was to achieve this house, this houseness.'' Mr. Palmer found his
title: THE CENSUS -- A Region of Enclaves: Canarsie, Brooklyn; 'For Sale' Signs Greet Newcomers

body: FOUR stops after the No. 3 IRT line rises out of its tunnel in the far reaches of Brooklyn, its elevated tracks enter East New York, looming above what was, less than a decade ago, a six-block stretch of weed-choked grassland. This was no natural habitat. That swath, criss-crossed by a street grid, was pockmarked in those days by the rusted hulks
title: East New York: a Neighborhood Reborn

body: Surely one of the most suburban parts of Brooklyn is the wrench-shaped peninsula that holds Bergen Beach, Georgetown, Mill Basin and Old Mill Basin. This area is embroidered with shady, quiet streets and mint-green lawns; down by the water, houses can sell for $1 million and more. Historically, the area has been overwhelmingly white, and remains
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHEAST BROOKLYN; Drops of Diversity in a Quiet Area

body: THE SETTING Among the sentimental masses as they shopped for the perfect Mother's Day card at Diamond's Hallmark Card Store in the Kings Plaza Shopping Center on Tuesday evening. Customers jostled as they looked for the words to ventriloquize their hearts. If you donned special X-ray glasses that showed the thought bubbles over their heads, you
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATLANDS -- BUZZ; When M-O-T-H-E-R Spells G-U-I-L-T

body: A Brooklyn man returning home from work was fatally shot on a crowded city bus Thursday night in what some witnesses said was a wordless encounter with another passenger, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Cory Pelzer, 22, was seated in the rear of the B82 bus riding eastbound on Flatlands Avenue near East 84th Street in Canarsie when he was
title: Bus Rider Fatally Shot

body: A part of the Flatlands section of Brooklyn will stay, well, flat, thanks to the City Planning Commission's rejection of a strip mall. The commission recently voted unanimously to deny an application for a shopping center with by a 54,000-square-foot ShopRite supermarket on a vacant lot on East 58th Street between Flatlands Avenue and Avenue J.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK SUPERMARKETS; Winners And a Loser In Rejection Of a Mall
